awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Children's Use of Online Social Networks Using the KidGab Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will support research into why children use social networks and how they influence each other using KidGab, a social network managed by the research team and designed for pre-teen Girl Scouts.  Although pre-teens regularly use social networks, relatively little is known about how they (versus adults) behave online or how this affects their well-being because most popular social networks close pre-teens' accounts when detected, while purpose-built networks for pre-teens are heavily restricted in terms of both what users can do and what data is available for study.  Building on their existing work with Girl Scout councils in Texas, the research team will develop new features and activities for KidGab and conduct outreach workshops with new councils.  This will allow the team to study how children respond to different recruitment and motivating ('gamification') strategies, in particular, looking at the relative value of adult- versus peer-created content and collaborative versus individual activities in encouraging continued use.  Through looking at how children create and adopt each other's drawings in visually-focused activities, the team will also develop novel methods for studying creativity, conformity, and influence in social networks.  In addition to making progress on these specific questions, the team's long-term research goal is to build a large enough network and dataset that both they and other researchers can conduct future studies and analyses.  More broadly, the team will create useful online content and design guidance for building social networks for pre-teens that support positive outcomes such as identity development and personal connection while reducing bad outcomes such as oversharing and cyberbullying.

Preliminary work by the team shows that the regular release of new content is critical to retaining participation; thus, the first main component of the proposal is to develop ways for children in the network to generate and share content such as personality quizzes, and images that network members can use virtual currency to buy and display on their profiles.  This will allow the team to (1) compare the uptake of adult-created versus peer-created content and their effects on encouraging long-term participation, (2) examine the kinds of content children prefer to generate and consume while generating a library of child-created content, and (3) study larger questions about identity creation and exploration.  The second main component is to develop sketching-based activities in which participants are given a creativity task and their work is made visible through the network so that other participants can adopt ideas from it in their own work.  The team will manually code key features of sketches generated for a given task and study their propagation using link-analysis algorithms such as PageRank and the Hubs and Authorities Algorithm, interpreting the degree to which a participant is a hub or authority as the likelihood that they are influenced by or influence others.  By looking at a variety of specific tasks and variations in instructions that prime behaviors, as well as characteristics of participants, the team will develop insights into key drivers of influence in pre-teens' social networks.  Further, the manually annotated sketches will provide training data for computer vision and machine learning algorithms for sketch analysis. The team will deploy these content creation mechanisms through events held with individual Scout councils geographically near those who have already participated in the network; such a strategy will best leverage the team's existing relationships with nearby councils while increasing the chance of recruiting dense sub-networks to encourage long-term retention.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Description

We have designed, developed, and deployed an online social network for a general population of children ages 7-12 called KidGab. Features of KidGab include most basic social networking components, but KidGab is designed to place as few restrictions on the user in order to maximize self-expressiveness on the platform. KidGab has unrestricted textual communication in the forms of public message (wall posts), private messages, and comments; a sketching interface that users can use to send messages or post to their own or friends' walls; a badge system called the "Digital Sash" where badges are earned from tasks that serve as inspiration for discussion and conversation; personality quizzes, Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Stories; personalized Avatars; and KidGab Coins and the KidGab Mall where the Coins are the website's reward currency for participating in the aforementioned activities and the Mall provides customization items for the avatars such as backgrounds, hairstyles, and clothing and accessories.

KidGab records every action a user makes on the site, (e.g., posts, comments, likes, logins, profile photo changes, etc.) rather than depending on self-reporting or interview strategies to understand what children really do online. This vast body of data has the potential to answer a myriad of research questions from the simplest participatory statistics to tendencies of conformity, from stylistic text analysis to online social support identification. Over the initial 450-day deployment, we recruited 271 Girl Scouts from our local Girl Scout council who served as our initial userbase. Since then, KidGab has grown to 915 users overall.

 

Intellectual Merit

KidGab provides insight into the behavioral characteristics of children on social networks, which is through its position as a large and self-sustaining social network that motivates participations via social networking affordances. Our experiments provide results regarding participatory interest with consideration to three new social networking features: crowd-sourcing content creation, child-created avatar components, and live collaborative experiments. We provide six main contributions from our 450 day deployment of KidGab: 1) active participation requires new features and content to be announced and released frequently, 2) gamified digital badge systems will not increase participation, but a currency system which leverages children?s acute desire to explore their identities does, 3) the main motivation for communicating online is the desire for positive feedback, not the desire to define their identities as self-reported, 4) children's interest in children's social networking sites can be fleeting; the median user remained active for a mere five hours, 5) parents want to be involved in their children's online social networking behavior, but they will not generally act on that desire, and 6) server reliability is paramount; uptime is essential to collect quality data and downtime drives away users.

Additionally, we provide results on the amount and patterns of conformity on online social networking sites for children. We found that priming children with examples significantly increases conformity in creative ideation tasks. We also found that priming with identity markers significantly increases the degree of conformity for those who tend to conform (but makes little difference for those who do not). Highly unique, highly conforming, and highly influential users exhibit significant and defining behaviors: highly unique users tend to choose expressive activities such as badge-earning; highly conforming users tend to choose socially forward activities, such as sketching and liking; and highly influential users tend to be highly motivated by new quiz releases, but tend not to be motivated by avatar component releases. We hope our results will inspire further research that may help to elucidate strategies to counter real-world risky digital behaviors that afflict adolescents, particularly those where peer influence and conformity are contributing factors.

 

Broader Impacts

Participation on KidGab provides the research world an extensive dataset of user actions and compositions. Being an already deployed, active social network, additional components such as games and learning modules can be added for testing and analysis for other research efforts. The sketch-based nature of KidGab provides an ever-growing, partially labeled dataset of child-authored sketches that is usable for sketch-based analysis.

In addition to the enrichment and social networking benefits from participating on KidGab, participants benefit from the learning activities and content-generation opportunities provided by KidGab intended to foster healthy online cybercitizenship skills such as avoiding digital predators, oversharing private information, and cyberbullying.

Outside of the expected uses of KidGab, eductors for a hazards education course used the KidGab software to refine the curriculum and teach natural hazards safety and risk perception to college students.


Last Modified: 02/28/2020
Modified by: Tracy A Hammond
